items.synopsis: The Fair Work Commission announces a 5.75 per cent increase in award wages, while the ASX rises on the back of gains on Wall Street overnight. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Fair Work announces 5.75 per cent rise in award wages; ASX rises as US government looks set to avoid debt default

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We initially heard from the Fair Work Commission that both the minimum wage and award wage would increase by 5.75% from July 1 — but there is a technicality that means 184,000 people are actually going to get a pay bump of 8.6%. Let me explain. The FWC spent a good chunk of its decision talking about the C14 classification. For the last 25 years, that classification has been aligned with the national minimum wage. In today's decision, the FWC is ending that alignment between C14 classification and the national minimum wage. Instead, the national minimum wage will be aligned with a slightly higher classification of C13 — and that classification's wage rate will jump by 5.75%. For those workers who were once on the C14 rate, it means they will be getting a total pay increase of 8.6%. That's why the minimum wage in dollar values is now $23.23 an hour, or $882.80 a week. If it were only a 5.75% increase, the hourly rate for those minimum wage workers would have been $22.60. But the FWC has framed the increase in the minimum wage as only being a 5.75% increase, because that's the size of the increase in the C13 classification rate that the minimum wage will now be aligned with.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Why is the minimum wage going up by 8.6% for some?

children.content: We initially heard from the Fair Work Commission that both the minimum wage and award wage would increase by 5.75% from July 1 — but there is a technicality that means 184,000 people are actually going to get a pay bump of 8.6%.
Let me explain.
The FWC spent a good chunk of its decision talking about the C14 classification. For the last 25 years, that classification has been aligned with the national minimum wage.
In today's decision, the FWC is ending that alignment between C14 classification and the national minimum wage.
Instead, the national minimum wage will be aligned with a slightly higher classification of C13 — and that classification's wage rate will jump by 5.75%.
For those workers who were once on the C14 rate, it means they will be getting a total pay increase of 8.6%.
That's why the minimum wage in dollar values is now $23.23 an hour, or $882.80 a week.
If it were only a 5.75% increase, the hourly rate for those minimum wage workers would have been $22.60.

But the FWC has framed the increase in the minimum wage as only being a 5.75% increase, because that's the size of the increase in the C13 classification rate that the minimum wage will now be aligned with.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: This is a pretty important question for a lot of Australian households who risk seeing a large part of their pay rise go straight back out to the bank if their mortgage rates rise further. RBC Capital Markets economist Su-Lin Ong believes today's wages decision, along with continued resilience in the Australian labour market and the potential for another US rate hike, will see the Reserve Bank hike interest rates twice more. "We have held a 3.85% terminal RBA forecast in our profile for some time but argued the risk was to the upside with the macro outlook suggesting that a more restrictive policy stance is prudent," she wrote in a note to clients. "Following several recent developments, including the outcome of today's minimum wage decision, we are adding a 25bp [basis point] hike to our RBA profile in June and another 25bp in July. "We are mindful of the poor optics for a hike next week following today's wage decision. If the RBA opts to pause again next week, hikes in July and August are likely." But there are plenty of economists who don't agree. "Given the magnitude, coverage and recent momentum ex-minimum wages, today's outcome seems consistent with the RBA's existing forecast so we don't expect any upward revisions to wages in the next forecast round (August)," wrote JP Morgan's Tom Kennedy. "By implication it also hasn't shifted our assessment for the RBA next week; we expect an on-hold decision and market pricing for a 35-40% chance of a 25bp hike seems fair ."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Will the award wages increase of 5.75% spark further interest rate rises?

children.content: This is a pretty important question for a lot of Australian households who risk seeing a large part of their pay rise go straight back out to the bank if their mortgage rates rise further.
RBC Capital Markets economist Su-Lin Ong
believes today's wages decision, along with continued resilience in the Australian labour market and the potential for another US rate hike, will see the Reserve Bank hike interest rates twice more.

"We have held a 3.85% terminal RBA forecast in our profile for some time but argued the risk was to the upside with the macro outlook suggesting that a more restrictive policy stance is prudent," she wrote in a note to clients.
"Following several recent developments, including the outcome of today's minimum wage decision,
we are adding a 25bp [basis point] hike to our RBA profile in June and another 25bp in July
"We are mindful of the poor optics for a hike next week following today's wage decision. If the RBA opts to pause again next week, hikes in July and August are likely."
But there are plenty of economists who don't agree.
"Given the magnitude, coverage and recent momentum ex-minimum wages,
today's outcome seems consistent with the RBA's existing forecast
so we don't expect any upward revisions to wages in the next forecast round (August)," wrote JP Morgan's Tom Kennedy.
"By implication it also hasn't shifted our assessment for the RBA next week;
we expect an on-hold decision and market pricing for a 35-40% chance of a 25bp hike seems fair

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: This year's minimum and award pay determination by the Fair Work Commission was pretty confusing. In the end, it turns out the very small group of workers (0.7% of workers, or about 100,000 people) on the lowest minimum wage of $21.38 an hour will see an 8.6% pay jump to $23.23 an hour. The bigger group (20.5% of workers, or around 2.8 million people) on award pay rates will see a 5.75% rise from their current pay rates. Got any questions about how this works and what it might mean for the economy? We'll do our best to answer.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Got any questions about the minimum and award pay increase?

children.content: This year's minimum and award pay determination by the Fair Work Commission was pretty confusing.
In the end, it turns out the very small group of workers (0.7% of workers, or about 100,000 people) on the lowest minimum wage of $21.38 an hour will see an 8.6% pay jump to $23.23 an hour.
The bigger group (20.5% of workers, or around 2.8 million people) on award pay rates will see a 5.75% rise from their current pay rates.
Got any questions about how this works and what it might mean for the economy?
We'll do our best to answer.
